author-notes.corresp: Fabio Manfredini, Vascular Diseases Center, C/o Centro Studi Biomedici applicati allo Sport, University of Ferrara, Via Gramicia 35, I-44123 Ferrara, Italy Email: mdf@unife.it

body.p: Emler and colleagues, 1 in this issue of Angiology, assess the usefulness of infrared photosensors to determine ankle–brachial pressure index (ABPI) and to detect peripheral arterial disease (PAD). The importance of obtaining simple, reliable and nonoperator-dependent measurements and the possible use of technology—infrared light in particular—for the study of PAD are key points of the study.

sec.title: Ankle–Brachial Pressure Index: From Local Vascular Index to Prognostic Cardiovascular Marker
sec.p: The ABPI test is a noninvasive tool for the diagnosis of PAD; it is obtained by comparing the systolic blood pressure (SBP) of the posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis arteries of each leg with the higher brachial pressure of either arm. 2 The success of this measurement derives from its easy execution, limited instrumentation needs, low cost, and early diagnosis of PAD.

Ankle–brachial pressure index represents the primary noninvasive screening test for PAD. 2 The ABPI also allows monitoring patients with claudication, 3 predicting functional decline, 4,5 and the follow-up after radiological or surgical intervention. 6 The ABPI also helps in determining the nature of leg ulcers, the rate of wound healing in relation to the arterial blood supply, and to optimize management. 7
,8

The ABPI has progressively assumed greater importance, going from a simple index of PAD to a sensitive measure of the “burden” of atherosclerosis and cardiovascular risk of asymptomatic patients. 9 A low ABPI (<0.90) at rest can define future cardiovascular risk, 2 since it is correlated with all-cause mortality independent of the Framingham Risk Score (FRS). 10 A rapid 1-year decline in resting and postexercise ABI is associated with all-cause mortality, cardiac events, stroke, and kidney failure in patients with PAD. 11

The inclusion of ABPI measurements in coronary heart disease risk-screening tools improves the identification of patients at moderate-to-high cardiovascular risk, 12 beyond the FRS. 10 A low ABPI is also an independent predictor of subsequent stroke recurrence risk, cardiovascular risk, and mortality in patients with acute stroke or transient ischemic attack. 13 –15 Moreover, the ABPI is useful for identifying the participants at higher risk of cognitive impairment and dementia. 16,17

sec.title: The ABPI: Limitations
sec.p: The continuous growth in ABPI use, the need to extend its use in screening programmes for large populations, and its possible determination not only by specialists but also by other professionals (eg, general practitioners, nurses, and vascular technicians) have raised some concerns. First, the capacity of ABPI <0.90 regarding the diagnosis of PAD in detecting >50% stenosis is high in terms of specificity and accuracy but low in terms of sensitivity with regard to the elderly and patients with diabetes mellitus (DM). 18 As regards patients with DM (41% of PAD patients have DM 19 ), patients with renal failure and, more generally, patients with arterial calcification and incompressible arteries, the efficiency of ABPI seems to be limited. 20,21 Again, low sensitivity was observed in its detection of mild PAD 22 and in the prediction of future cardiovascular outcomes, together with high specificity. 23

Although the different methods of ABPI determination do not substantially influence the strength of the associations between PAD and cardiovascular events, they can affect the estimation of PAD prevalence. 24 The best way to determine ABPI, 25 aiming at identifying more patients at risk, should be considered (eg, using the lower instead of the higher ankle pressure). 26 Doubts may derive from (i) the influence on ABPI of brachial SBP that might be different in hypotensive and hypertensive patients, 27 (ii) the standardization of measurement procedures (patient position and synchronous SBP measurement at upper and lower limbs), (iii) the possible influence of intra- and interobserver reliability, 28 (iv) the time necessary to perform a correct measurement, 29 and (v) the need for skilled operators to obtain consistent, accurate results. 30

Thus, despite the need to identify patients with PAD at higher cardiovascular risk and to manage their risk factors aggressively, these critical points shed doubt on the wisdom of routine ABPI screening. In fact, such screening, with different degrees of recommendation (levels B-C), is reserved for selected populations, for example, participants with exertional leg symptoms, participants aged 50 to 69 with cardiovascular risk factors, patients older than 70 years, and participants with a 10-year risk of a cardiovascular event between 10% and 20%. 1

sec.title: The ABPI Measurement: A Light in the Dark?
sec.p: A major need in terms of ABPI screening for PAD, especially in primary care settings, is to obtain measures that are inexpensive, quick, safe, repeatable, accurate and that can be acquired by personnel with limited training. 31,32 As regards costs, the use of a pocket Doppler instead of vascular laboratory equipment for PAD screening 33 and the introduction of new methods of technological instrumentation for automatic measurement could help to ameliorate some of the critical issues mentioned above. Automated oscillometric devices, which are commonly used for BP determination, can measure ABPI reliably, easily, and accurately compared with measurement by continuous-wave Doppler ultrasound, 31 even in participants with various cardiovascular risk profiles. 34 However, they carry the risk of falsely categorizing patients with PAD. 35,36

Photoplethysmography (PPG), a simple and low-cost optical technique, is used in a wide range of medical devices for measuring oxygen saturation. The PPG, detecting blood volume changes in microvascular beds and operating at a red or a near-infrared wavelength, 37 has been used and evaluated. The ABPI automatic measurement by PPG is fast and accurate, 38 representing an effective alternative to Doppler ABPI but requiring improvement to increase the sensitivity and specificity of the system for patients with type 2 DM. 39 Light, in particular, is a protagonist in the study of vascular diseases with near-infrared spectroscopy (NIRS), another noninvasive technique that allows real-time monitoring of blood perfusion and tissue oxygenation. 40 –42 In PAD, NIRS devices provide information on local blood flow and oxygen consumption, 43,44 support the diagnosis, and severity evaluation of PAD by means of static and dynamic measures correlated with the ABPI. 45 –47

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The PAD affects 12% to 20% of Americans ≥ 65 years of age but, in the general population, only ≈10% of people with PAD present with the classic symptom of intermittent claudication. 15 The PAD is also a marker of systemic atherosclerosis. Therefore, an early diagnosis is important. The ABPI is also a useful indicator of overall vascular risk; therefore, there is a need for improvements in its measurement. Techniques and devices available for ABPI measurement must be carefully validated.
